title: November R-Ladies meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on November 19th at 1pm on campus at UCLA. At our last meeting everyone was enthusiastic about writing an R package together! The more experienced group members can take the lead on the coding while we all learn and work along together.

To narrow our focus, we would like to analyze a dataset from the city of LA made public at data.lacity.org.

For November we should focus on picking a dataset and a general question. So browse through the open datasets and brainstorm a few ideas. At our meetup we can take turns describing particularly interesting data sets and at the end we'll vote on the choice for our package.

We'll make all of the code public as we go and hopefully end up with a fun package at the end.

See you there!
Katie
katie@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 325 in the Botany building. If you enter from Charles E Young Drive South, 325 is the first room on the left (the entrance is on the third floor). We'll prop the door open, but if it happens to be locked, just send a tweet to @RLadiesLA and we'll let you in.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: First RLadies meetup!
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We'll be having our first meeting on October 15th at 1pm on campus at UCLA. We'll do short presentations on examples of using R in STEM research and leave plenty of time for socializing. There will be snacks.

We'll be in room 325 in the Botany building. If you enter from Charles E Young Drive South, 325 is the first room on the left (the entrance is on the third floor). We'll prop the door open, but if it happens to be locked, just send a message on meetup http://www.meetup.com/rladies-la or a tweet to @RLadiesLA and we'll let you in.

Send me an email (katie@rladies.org) or a tweet if you'd like to give a short, no pressure presentation of your work. Hopefully we can get enough presenters to do 5 minute lightning talks :)

Excited to meet all of you!!

Katie

PS - The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: Collaborative Data Science with Kaggle Kernels and Datasets
description:
RLadies Los Angeles and LA Women Who Code are excited to present

Collaborative Data Science with Kaggle Kernels and Datasets

by Megan Risdal

Code and data sharing in collaboration with others is integral to open data science. On Kaggle, the world’s largest online data science community, users use Kernels as a platform to share and execute reproducible code and Datasets to access, analyze, and maintain public data projects. Since the introduction of Kernels in 2015, users have written tens of thousand of kernels in R, Python, and Julia. And in the past year, users and organizations have published over 2,000 public datasets. Over this time, Kernels and Datasets have transformed how the data science community tackles machine learning problems, collaborates, and learns. In this talk, Megan Risdal uses community metrics and insights to share what Kernels and Datasets have taught Kaggle about collaborative data science.

Megan (https://twitter.com/MeganRisdal) is a Community Advocate and Data Scientist at Kaggle. She holds master’s degrees in linguistics from UCLA and North Carolina State University.

Where: Google Venice (https://www.google.com/maps/place/400+Hampton+Dr,+Venice,+CA+90291/@33.9954407,-118.4757689,20z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x80c2bacf14e5fcb9:0x325955854edc3b52!8m2!3d33.9955779!4d-118.4760707), 400 Hampton Drive, Venice 90291

(Note: Enter through the gate on Sunset here: https://goo.gl/QwgtQf ).

When: Tuesday October 17th, 2017

6.00: Doors open, food and drinks served.

7.00: Talk start.

8.00: Talk end.

Unfortunately parking will not be provided, but there are public parking lots close by.

Food and drinks will be provided.

Bring photo ID - we cannot admit without it. Please do not attend if you are not on the list of registered attendees.

Please be Googley (http://www.businessinsider.com/the-meanings-of-googliness-2013-8), and if you’re not going to be able to attend, cancel so that someone else can attend instead.

title: Knowledge Architecture: Framework to extract and share knowledge
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on July 10th at 7:30pm in Pasadena. We're fortunate to be hosted by the great folks at Supplyframe (https://supplyframe.com/).

We have an exciting guest, David Meza (https://twitter.com/davidmeza1), Chief Knowledge Architect, NASA. In this presentation, David will introduce a framework for organizations to extract knowledge, via data science, from their data and effectively present to their end user. Examples, with code, will be demonstrated to the audience.

See you there!
Katie
katie@rladies.org

venues.name: Supplyframe DesignLab
venues.address: 30 East Del Mar Boulevard Pasadena, CA

title: The grammar of graphics: ggplot2 April RLadies meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on April 16th at 1pm on campus at UCLA.

The next stop on our Tour de R will be "The Grammar of Graphics" with ggplot2. Bring your laptops: we'll provide code and you can work along with us. First Katie Scranton (https://twitter.com/DrScranto) give a short intro to base plot and basics of ggplot2, then Christine Zhang (https://twitter.com/christinezhang) will go further into ggplot2, with examples.

We are limiting this meetup to people who identify as female/gender non-conforming/trans/other.

See you there!
Katie
katie@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 325 in the Botany building. If you enter from Charles E Young Drive South, 325 is the first room on the left (the entrance is on the third floor). We'll prop the door open, but if it happens to be locked, just send a tweet to @RLadiesLA and we'll let you in.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: February RLadies meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on February 18th at 1pm on campus at UCLA.

It will be the first stop on our Tour de R! Inspired by RLadies London and the global RLadies community, we will visit one topic in R each month, providing code so everyone can work along. Please vote on which topics we include and suggest ones I missed!
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe908TMxg6reD5xrwU2DOmke6wprlycVleCpIGzP17RXmyzFg/viewform
We'll start with one of the most popular choices. Also email me if you would be willing to lead any of the stops on these (or another) topic.

See you there!
Katie
katie@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 325 in the Botany building. If you enter from Charles E Young Drive South, 325 is the first room on the left (the entrance is on the third floor). We'll prop the door open, but if it happens to be locked, just send a tweet to @RLadiesLA and we'll let you in.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: Version control with Git and R! R-Ladies December meetup
description:
Think holiday cheer and version control don’t go together? Think again! In this meetup we’ll introduce you to version controlling your R code with Git and RStudio and using browsing and collaboration features of GitHub.

All you need is a laptop, no worries if you don’t have git set up on your computer yet. However, if you get a chance before the meetup, write down your most (or least!) favourite R error that you encounter regularly and an emoji translation for it. During the workshop you’ll get a chance to submit a pull request to [errormoji](https://github.com/mine-cetinkaya-rundel/errormoji) with your translation.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
la@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 101 of the LaKretz Garden Pavilion, located in the botanical garden at the corner of Tiverton Dr and Charles E Young Dr South. The best way to get to room 101 is by taking the path off of Tiverton Dr into the garden.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: Code Smells with Jenny Bryan! November R-Ladies meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on November 29th at 6pm at the USC Health Sciences Campus. We're delighted to welcome our guest speaker Jenny Bryan, as well as R-Ladies Irvine and R-Ladies Pasadena members!

We’ll be talking about "code smells": what makes your code distinctive from other people's code and what makes it feel elegant versus messy.

Please note that we'll be requiring tickets as there is limited seating; your non-gender minority friends are welcome to come, but must get guest tickets from you. Tickets are available here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/r-ladies-la-meetup-with-jenny-bryan-tickets-52038070269

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
la@rladies.org

title: Dirty Data! R-Ladies October meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on October 27th at 12pm on campus at UCLA.

We’ll be talking about dirty data: whether messiness comes from the format of the data, converting data types from one to another, or if the underlying data itself isn’t how you would like. We will cover tidy data and its concepts and packages, as well as workflows to figure out what kind of dirtiness you’re seeing. Our focus will primarily be on methods and packages, but we will give a quick overview of the underlying statistical principles of missingness and outliers.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
la@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 101 of the LaKretz Garden Pavilion, located in the botanical garden at the corner of Tiverton Dr and Charles E Young Dr South. The best way to get to room 101 is by taking the path off of Tiverton Dr into the garden.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: Summer Recap: Data Viz, Packages, Shiny! R-Ladies September meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on September 22nd at 12pm on campus at UCLA. Apologies for the short notice: UCLA starts back up next week so life has been a bit hectic in the past two weeks.

Several people have contacted me about having missed meetups this summer, so this one is for you! We'll briefly go over the topics we covered this summer and go into more depth as there is interest. Those topics were: Shiny apps, data visualization, and writing programs and packages.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on July 28th at 12pm on campus at UCLA.

This month we'll be covering data visualization! We'll talk about best practices, base R graphics vs. ggplot, some of the new features in the recent release of ggplot, and how to tweak output in R to better suit your needs (including gridextra and ggsave).

title: Everything shiny! R-Ladies June meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on June 23rd at 12pm on campus at UCLA.

Local LA R-Lady Lauren Steely will be walking us through the world of shiny! Shiny is great for building web apps that let other people explore your datasets without having to be technical R users. By the end we will have built two simple shiny apps for visualizing some scientific data. Make sure you have RStudio installed with the `shiny` package.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Lauren Steely and Katie Leap
la@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 101 of the LaKretz Garden Pavilion, located in the botanical garden at the corner of Tiverton Dr and Charles E Young Dr South. The best way to get to room 101 is by taking the path off of Tiverton Dr into the garden. Follow the R-Ladies signs!
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: R Markdown: blogdown and plotly
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on May 19th at 12pm on campus at UCLA.

We'll be diving into the world of R Markdown, exploring the different types of documents you can make, adding figures with plotly, and making a website with blogdown. Bring your laptops: we'll provide code and you can work along with us. Only some basic familiarity with R and RStudio is necessary. Make sure you have RStudio installed with packages: `rmarkdown`, `knitr`, and `plotly`.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct (https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct).

See you there!
Katie Scranton and Katie Leap
la@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 101 of the LaKretz Garden Pavilion, located in the botanical garden at the corner of Tiverton Dr and Charles E Young Dr South. The best way to get to room 101 is by taking the path off of Tiverton Dr into the garden. Follow the R-Ladies signs!
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: purrr: Functional programming in R at the April RLadies meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R Ladies!

We're back!! We'll be having our next meetup on April 28th at 12pm on campus at UCLA.

We'll be continuing our adventures in the tidyverse, using the purrr package for functional programming in R. Bring your laptops: we'll provide code and you can work along with us. Only some basic familiarity with R and the tidyverse is necessary. Make sure you have purrr installed before the meetup.
http://purrr.tidyverse.org/
https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr

We are also excited to introduce our new co-organizer: Katie Leap!!(https://twitter.com/katie_leap).

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Scranton
katie@rladies.org

Location details:
We'll be in room 101 of the LaKretz Garden Pavilion, located in the botanical garden at the corner of Tiverton Dr and Charles E Young Dr South. The best way to get to room 101 is by taking the path off of Tiverton Dr into the garden. Follow the R-Ladies signs!
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 2 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

title: End of year shindig! R-Ladies December meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on December 7th at 11 am on campus at UCLA. This event will be a social one, but please bring your ideas for future meetups!

Update: The wonderful folks at RStudio sent us a big bag of package hex stickers! Bring your laptop/water bottle/whatever and let's decorate! Also, we're going to try out a tidyverse-based murder mystery game put together by fellow RLady Vebashini Naidoo! You can check it out in advance here: https://github.com/sciencificity/reclues.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
kleap@ucla.edu

Location details:
We'll be in room 122 of Geffen Hall, located at the corner of Le Conte Ave and Tiverton Dr, across the street from Ralph's.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 18 and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

venues.name: David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA

title: Advanced R Book Club Part 6: Performance!
description:
The LA West R Users Group and RLadies LA teamed up for a book club series focused on Hadley Wickham’s ‘Advanced R’! This will be our last session, covering ways to improve the performance of your R code!

Slides and materials from the previous Advanced R sessions:
https://github.com/amy17519/adv-r-bookclub

Where: UCLA Charles E. Young Research Library, West Classroom (Room 23167)

Directions: Look for West Classroom (Room 23167) after entering the library. Consider public transit or rideshare if you live nearby since you need to pay for parking. UCLA Parking Structure 5 & 3, both are walking distance to the library. See www.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors

When: Saturday, November 9 at 10am

Why: "The book is designed primarily for R users who want to improve their programming skills and understanding of the language. It should also be useful for programmers coming to R from other languages, as help you to understand why R works the way it does." - Hadley Wickham

Come join us for coffee and #rstats as we tackle the book’s sections one at a time. Each book club session will have a leader to guide the discussion, and we encourage everyone to take a look at the material beforehand. The full text of the book is online for free at https://adv-r.hadley.nz/, and there's an exercise answer guide at https://advanced-r-solutions.rbind.io/.

Here’s the schedule:
• Foundations - August 3, session leader was Amanda Tilot
• Functional Programming - August 10, session leader was Amy Tzu-Yu Chen
• OO Programming - split over August 24 (Base Types, S3, and R6) and September 7 (S4 and Trade-offs), session leader was Daniel Jacobs
• Metaprogramming - split over September 21 (Ch 17, 18, 19) and October 5 (Ch 20, 21), session leader will be Emil Hvitfeldt!
• **Techniques - split over October 19 (Ch 22, 23) and November 9 (Ch 24, 25), session leaders will be Jake Kramer and Malcolm Barrett respectively!**

Advanced R dives deep into how R works as a language, and we highly recommend joining us for the first two sessions if you’re relatively new to R. We’re also looking for discussion leaders for the later sections of the book, so please reach out to Amy or Amanda if interested!

This is a bring-your-own-coffee series, but we'll try to provide something sweet. As we're cohosting with the LA West RUG, all R users are welcome! Lastly, we expect all attendees to abide by the RLadies Code of Conduct, available here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la.

See you there!
Amanda & Amy

"This is the perfect book for someone who wants to understand R at a level slightly deeper than necessary for an analyst and less than a base R contributor. If you're interested in programming language design or at looking under the hood of R, this book rocks. " - Goodreads review

**To become more involved**
Invite yourself to our SoCal R Users Slack group and join #adv-r-bookclub for discussions: http://bit.ly/laerug
Check out more events: laocr.org/

Here’s the schedule:
• Foundations - August 3, session leader was Amanda Tilot
• Functional Programming - August 10, session leader was Amy Tzu-Yu Chen
• OO Programming - split over August 24 (Base Types, S3, and R6) and September 7 (S4 and Trade-offs), session leader was Daniel Jacobs
• **Metaprogramming - split over September 21 (Ch 17, 18, 19) and October 5 (Ch 20, 21), session leader will be Emil Hvitfeldt!**
• Techniques - split over October 19 (Ch 22, 23) and November 2 (Ch 24, 25), session leaders will be Jake Kramer and Malcolm Barrett respectively!

Advanced R dives deep into how R works as a language, and we highly recommend joining us for the first two sessions if you’re relatively new to R. We’re also looking for discussion leaders for the later sections of the book, so please reach out to Amy or Amanda if interested!

This is a buy-your-own-coffee event, so let's support Literati Cafe. As we're cohosting with the LA West RUG, all R users are welcome! Lastly, we expect all attendees to abide by the RLadies Code of Conduct, available here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la.

See you there!
Amanda & Amy

"This is the perfect book for someone who wants to understand R at a level slightly deeper than necessary for an analyst and less than a base R contributor. If you're interested in programming language design or at looking under the hood of R, this book rocks. " - Goodreads review

**To become more involved**
Invite yourself to our SoCal R Users Slack group and join #adv-r-bookclub for discussions: http://bit.ly/laerug
Check out more events: laocr.org/

title: Advanced R Book Club Part 3b: Object Oriented Programming
description:
The LA West R Users Group and RLadies LA are teaming up for a book club series focused on Hadley Wickham’s ‘Advanced R’!

Where: UCLA Charles E. Young Research Library, West Classroom (Room 23167)

Directions: Look for West Classroom (Room 23167) after entering the library. Consider public transit or rideshare if you live nearby since you need to pay for parking. UCLA Parking Structure 5 & 3, both are walking distance to the library. See www.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors

When: 10 am, Saturday, September 7th

Why: "The book is designed primarily for R users who want to improve their programming skills and understanding of the language. It should also be useful for programmers coming to R from other languages, as help you to understand why R works the way it does." - Hadley Wickham

Come join us for coffee and #rstats as we tackle the book’s sections one at a time. Each book club session will have a leader to guide the discussion, and we encourage everyone to take a look at the material beforehand. The full text of the book is online for free at https://adv-r.hadley.nz/, and there's an exercise answer guide at https://advanced-r-solutions.rbind.io/.

• Foundations - August 3, session leader was Amanda Tilot
• Functional Programming - August 10, session leader was Amy Tzu-Yu Chen

• Techniques - split over October 19 (Ch 22, 23) and November 2 (Ch 24, 25), session leaders will be Jake Kramer and Malcolm Barrett respectively!

Advanced R dives deep into how R works as a language, and we highly recommend joining us for the first two sessions if you’re relatively new to R. We’re also looking for discussion leaders for the later sections of the book, so please reach out to Amy or Amanda if interested!

This is a bring-your-own-coffee series, but we'll try to provide something sweet. As we're cohosting with the LA West RUG, all R users are welcome! Lastly, we expect all attendees to abide by the RLadies Code of Conduct, available here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la.

See you there!
Amanda & Amy

title: Reducing Bias in Algorithms! R-Ladies January meetup
description:
Hi Los Angeles R-Ladies!

We'll be having our next meetup on January 26th at 10am (note earlier time!) on campus at UCLA. In addition to an earlier time, we'll also be in a different location! However, it is very close to the previous one.

We’ll be welcoming a guest speaker, RLady Gwynn Sturdevant, to talk about reducing bias in algorithms. This talk will give some examples of algorithms that are biased and the consequences that ensue. Unfortunately, developing equitable algorithms is mathematically complex, and there is no simple way to do so. We will discuss two suggested methods and their drawbacks and conclude with a discussion of ethical matrices.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
kleap@ucla.edu

Location details:
We'll be in room 113 of Geffen Hall, located at the corner of Le Conte Ave and Tiverton Dr, across the street from Ralph's.
The closest visitor parking is parking structure 18 (and it is much closer than parking structure 2 is to our regular meeting spot) and it is $3 per hour. There is also street parking on Hilgard Ave and the surrounding neighborhood. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors/pay-station-rates-and-locations

venues.name: David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA

title: useR2020 Tutorial: "Causal Inference in R" (Underrepresented groups signup)
description:
RLadies LA is teaming up with this year's virtual useR! 2020 conference to host a casual inference tutorial hosted by Dr. Lucy D'Agostino McGowan and Dr. Malcom Barrett! See bottom of post for important logistical details.

Description: In both data science and academic research, prediction modeling is often not enough; to answer many questions, we need to approach them causally. In this workshop, we’ll teach the essential elements of answering causal questions in R through causal diagrams, and causal modeling techniques such as propensity scores and inverse probability weighting. We’ll also show that by distinguishing predictive models from causal models, we can better take advantage of both tools. You’ll be able to use the tools you already know--the tidyverse, regression models, and more--to answer the questions that are important to your work.

Audience: This tutorial will appeal to statisticians and data scientists interested in taking their inference to the next level, incorporating causal techniques.

Logistical notes:
* This is the sign-up page for anyone who is a member of an underrepresented group.
* We have a separate sign-up page (here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la/events/271909700/) for anyone who does not identify as part of an underrepresented group. Please RSVP on only one page. Thank you for helping us support diversity in #rstats!
* The tutorial will have live closed captioning available (you can turn it on from within Zoom)
* The Zoom room will have a password, which we will email to attendees before the event. Please check your email so that you can join us!

Questions? Leave a comment or send us a message!

See you on July 27!

Your RLadies LA hosts,
Amanda & Katie

title: Data Visualization - A Lesser Known Intro
description:
Hello RLadies!

We're back for our June virtual meetup!

Our speaker will be Amy Tzu-Yu Chen, Organizer of LA R Users Group.
***
Abstract: This is a practical introduction to data visualization. We will start with a brief history of data visualization. Then, I will share some of my strategy, process, and toolbox for data visualization. I will be using ggplot2, but the visualization skills you learn from this talk will be transferrable to other visualization packages.
***
Have a question about data visualization that you'd like Amy to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

The Zoom link is available once you RSVP.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Amanda & Katie
@aktilot, @katie_leap

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda (amanda.k.tilot@gmail.com) or Katie (kleap@ucla.edu).

title: RLadies LA May Virtual Meetup: Writing Functions!
description:
Hello RLadies!

We're back for another virtual meetup! Katie Leap will be giving a workshop about writing functions. We'll discuss when you need to write a function, how they're written, how to find functions that already exist, how to adapt code into functions, and how to use the ideas behind functional programming to make your life easier.

Have a question about functions that you'd like Katie to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

The Zoom link is available once you RSVP. All materials from the tutorial will be available on Github afterward.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Katie Leap
@katie_leap

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda (amanda.k.tilot@gmail.com) or Katie (kleap@ucla.edu).

title: RLadies LA RMarkdown Virtual Meetup!
description:
Hello RLadies!

Due to the coronavirus situation in LA County, RLadies LA and our other local R users groups are moving our usual meetups online for the next few months. Our first virtual meetup will be Saturday, March 28, at 10am. Amanda Tilot will give a tutorial on using RMarkdown for data analysis and reporting.

"Better data communication & organization with RMarkdown"

What do a static PDF, an interactive HTML document, a personal website, and a slide deck all have in common? You can build them in R with RMarkdown! In this tutorial, we'll work through some common scenarios where RMarkdown can help improve your data communication and organization.

* Shifting from R script files + lots of #comments to RMarkdown notebooks
* Turning your R code into HTML, PDFs, and Word docs with knitr
* Enhancing your RMarkdown files with text formatting and presentation options
* Doing more with code chunks: SQL queries & background jobs

**Schedule**
10:00a - 10:15a Open Zoom, come say hi!
10:15a - 11:00 RMarkdown tutorial
11:00 - 11:15 Extra Q&A, planning future sessions

Have a question about using RMarkdown that you'd like Amanda to cover? Post a comment on the event page!

We'll send out a Zoom link to all attendees closer to the 28th, and include instructions for joining the meetup. All materials from the tutorial will be available on Github afterward.

As always we welcome people regardless of gender, but our group is intended for those who identify with a gender minority (trans women, cis women, trans men, non-binary, other). We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct.

See you there!
Amanda Tilot
@aktilot

PS: We're always looking for presenters! If you're interested, please reach out to Amanda (amanda.k.tilot@gmail.com) or Katie (kleap@ucla.edu).

title: RLadies February Study Group
description:
Join us at Literati Cafe on Wilshire Blvd. for dedicated time to get help with R or work on a coding project! Katie and Amanda will be there for help and support, so feel free to drop by with a question or stay and work!

No need to come right at 6:30 or stay until 9:00, we'll be there the whole time.
